body:
You can set the execution mode to "automation", though I think it's considerably slower. 
https://kylebarron.github.io/stata_kernel/using_stata_kernel/configuration/#execution_mode

I don't know why Stata IC wouldn't include the console version?

Apparently it's not a premium enough of a version?

Setting it to automation leads to an error about needing to activate StataIC? 

Do you want the traceback as well?

It's fixed on master. 
```
pip install git+https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel --upgrade
```
It seems that Stata prints output to the GUI much slower on Mac than on Windows, and so that's why automation mode is so slow on a mac

Sorry, installing the git master branch and changing to automation still leads to the same problem. Here's the traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/stata_kernel/__main__.py", line 4, in <module>
    IPKernelApp.launch_instance(kernel_class=StataKernel)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/traitlets/config/application.py", line 657, in launch_instance
    app.initialize(argv)
  File "<decorator-gen-123>", line 2, in initialize
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/traitlets/config/application.py", line 87, in catch_config_error
    return method(app, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ipykernel/kernelapp.py", line 484, in initialize
    self.init_kernel()
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ipykernel/kernelapp.py", line 389, in init_kernel
    user_ns=self.user_ns,
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/traitlets/config/configurable.py", line 412, in instance
    inst = cls(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/stata_kernel/kernel.py", line 73, in __init__
    self.stata = StataSession(self, self.conf)
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/stata_kernel/stata_session.py", line 89, in __init__
    self.init_mac_automation()
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/stata_kernel/stata_session.py", line 165, in init_mac_automation
    self.automate(cmd_name='activate')
  File "/Users/adrianagaviria/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/stata_kernel/stata_session.py", line 513, in automate
    raise OSError(res.stderr.decode('utf-8') + '\nInput: ' + cmd)
OSError: 26:27: syntax error: Se esperaba final de línea pero se encontró “"”. (-2741)

Input: tell application "StataIC"" to activate
```
You have an extra " there. Try putting the path to Stata in the configuration file without quotes

oh man... that was dumb, sorry for that. It worked. Thank you for your help!

On Tue, Jan 8, 2019 at 2:12 PM Kyle Barron <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> You have an extra " there. Try putting the path to Stata in the
> configuration file without quotes
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/282#issuecomment-452417045>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGFXhEESM44vXHNAga9d8y8k0o1IJQOZks5vBO2TgaJpZM4Z18lM>
> .
>

@lordflaron By the way, I have Stata 13 IC for Unix and that comes with a console. Surprised that is not the case in OSX. Perhaps the path to the executable is non-obvious? (e.g. `/usr/local/bin/stata` or something along those lines?)

Nope, Stata IC on Mac doesn't come with a console version, see https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/189#issuecomment-423013078 (`StataIC` is the GUI version; the console version would be named something like `stata-ic`). Honestly I'm guessing StataCorp just forgot to include it with the Mac IC distribution.

Yeah, I was pretty surprised myself, but I have Linux so I didn't know all
these challenges when I was writing up my slides. I use arch, btw.

On Tue, Jan 8, 2019 at 2:42 PM Kyle Barron <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Nope, Stata IC on Mac doesn't come with a console version, see #189
> (comment)
> <https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/189#issuecomment-423013078>.
> Honestly I'm guessing StataCorp just forgot to include it with the Mac IC
> distribution.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

And you probably didn't expect me to introduce a bug in the released windows version either!

> I use arch, btw.

@kylebarron: See? Everyone uses Arch. Take the plunge, all the cool kinds are doing it!

@lordflaron @mcaceresb 

In case you were wondering why StataCorp doesn't supply a Stata IC console version for Mac (tl;dr "pay more, you guys aren't power users!")

From Stata support:

> Unix operating systems often have an optional graphical user interface so we
> need to include console versions of Stata for all flavors of Stata on those
> systems. 
> 
> The Mac operating system always has a graphical user interface so the console
> version of Stata on the Mac is a special tool that is included for power users.
> The Stata/IC for Mac is designed for regular Stata users and does not include a
> console version.
> 
> Originally the Mac versions of Stata were just like the Windows versions and
> did not have any console support.

Oh man... No words
